entries.meaning: (uncountable) Similarity or resemblance to something else.
examples: Renaissance man thought in terms of similitudes: the theatre of life, the mirror of nature. […]Aemulation was similitude within distance: the sky resembled a face because it had “eyes” — the sun and moon.

entries.meaning: (countable) A way in which two people or things share similitude.
examples: Renaissance man thought in terms of 'similitudes': the theatre of life, the mirror of nature. […]Aemulation was similitude within distance: the sky resembled a face because it had “eyes” — the sun and moon.

entries.meaning: (countable) Someone or something that closely resembles another; a duplicate or twin.
examples: If I was certain of anything in the world, I was certain that I had seen my brother in the study — nay, more, had touched him, — and equally certain that I had seen his double — his exact similitude, in the garden.
